newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysian activists protest ASEAN meeting on Burma.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian activists protest ASEAN meeting on Burma.

text.p: Malaysian rights activists on Friday protested Burma's planned entry into the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) ahead of a weekend meeting expected to decide when Rangoon will be admitted to the regional grouping.

"We call on ASEAN governments to abandon their failed policy of constructive engagement and deny ASEAN membership (to Burma)," Fan Yew Teng, spokesman for the group of 22 Malaysian non-governmental organisations, said in a memorandum.

The activists, carrying placards calling Burma's military rulers "murderers, criminals and drug traffickers", staged the protest outside the foreign ministry, where they handed over the memorandum to a ministry official.

Fan said that since ASEAN launched its "constructive engagement" policy in 1991, "there has been absolutely no movement on the part of (the military government) towards democracy by way of handing power to the duly elected representatives of the Burmese people".
ASEAN says its policy toward Burma is aimed at reforming the regime from within and keeping it from becoming isolated.
Foreign ministers from ASEAN -- Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam -- were due to arrive in Kuala Lumpur on Friday for the meeting on Saturday.
ASEAN has already decided to admit Burma, Cambodia and Laos as a group this year. The meeting is to decide exactly when.

Malaysia, this year's ASEAN chairman, has been pressing for the three to be inducted at ASEAN's annual ministerial meeting scheduled for July 24-25 in Kuala Lumpur. Another proposal would admit the three at an informal ASEAN summit in December, to which Japan, South Korea and China have also be invited.
